H0.text: Surface water evaporating into the atmosphere is an example of gravity influencing other systems, since gravity, defined as a force of attraction between objects, has effects that can be witnessed in many natural processes.

H1.text: Planets moving around the Sun in an elliptical pattern are an example of gravity influencing other systems.

H2.text: Glaciers melting because of increasing temperatures is an example of gravity influencing other systems, showing that gravity—defined as a force of attraction between objects—can affect many systems.

H3.text: Groundwater moving to the surface in an artesian well is an example of gravity influencing other systems, as gravity is a force of attraction between objects whose effects are witnessed in many systems.

A4.text: To a close approximation, planets and satellites follow elliptic orbits, with the center of mass being orbited at a focal point of the ellipse, as described by Kepler's laws of planetary motion.
